title: Financial Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Houston System (Houston, TX)
Interview Descriptions:
I left the interview feeling like it went fairly well but within 24 hours received a generic rejection letter. Looking back although I felt comfortable and felt the interview questions were easy, it wasn’t very conversational like most interviews I have. They were just taking turns reading questions off a sheet and writing my answers. Here and there I’d get a response to my answers. I really think they already knew who they wanted to hire and were just going through the motions. 

There were some subtle clues that I didn’t pick up on until after I got rejected like after the interview, no one even walked me back to the elevators or main hallway. They just let me out of the conference room and asked if I knew how to get back myself and then immediately closed the conference door back. So I think they went straight to discussing me/my interview.

I help with interviewing and hiring candidates at my current job and usually no one is immediately rejected unless they did something specific in the interview that really turned the team off... That could just be my jobs way but if I did do something wrong, I have no clue what it was. That’s why my only other guess is they already knew who they were going to hire and were just going through the motions... again my job doesn’t do that. They don’t bring a lot of people in to interview. Only top choices that they’re pretty sure they want to hire based on resume and phone interview. My job doesn’t like to waste their time or others.

Another subtle clue I got was that, when I asked, I was told I’d hear back within a couple of days whether I got the job or not, by email. If they wanted to hire me, it often takes longer than a day or 2 to even get references checked. I just hate when employers waste my time like that because I already have a full time job and have to waste PTO and/or work extra hours to make up the time. I had also let my references know I had an interview and they might be called, which I wish I hadn’t.

Another FYI, the campus is huge. Parking can be confusing and you will probably have a long walk from parking to where your interview is. I suggest planning to arrive 30 minutes before the interview start time because it may take that long to find parking and walk to the building. Also, you have to pay for parking and they didn’t validate or reimburse me at all. I’ve NEVER had to pay for parking for an interview. I think the fact I didn’t get it was probably a blessing!
Interview Questions: Why should we hire you over other candidates? Name 3 strengths and 2 weakness.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Houston System (Houston, TX) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Positions for Research Assistants are based on individual research for the Masters Program which are consistent with the needs and direction of federal funding for NSF research.  Hiring Managers are typically Associate Professors, with ongoing research in a dedicated field of study.  Potential candidates are identified by Project Managers or Associate Professors, which have hand selected exceptional Masters students based on professional experience and comprehensive understanding of Network Communication Engineering.  The Associate Professors interview selectively based on recommendations and resume screening processes.  

Once the candidates are narrowed down,  a face-to-face interview is conducted with validation of core components needed to continue existing research and configuration work for publication and presentation at multiple preselected conferences.

Research Assistant positions require ability to conduct complex network activites, detailed research in new networking technologies and exceptional public speaking skills for presentation of work
Interview Questions:
Interview questions consist of technical and interpersonal scenarios which the Research Assistant will be required to execute.  Specific questions regarding programming languages, syntax, and documentation practices are discussed and used to determine level of proficiency in these areas.  Candidates are questioned on their professional and personal objectives to ensure there is alignment with the core Research goals.  

Since research is a continuation of previous works, questions regarding publications produced from that department are asked.

title: Program Manager Interview

How do you handle an agitated employee, faculty, staff, or student?

What can you bring to the table that other candidates can not?

What was your biggest failure?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Houston System (Houston, TX) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: The interview process is essentially a formality. Hiring decision are made prior to actually meeting anyone, and are based on publication record, references, and personal connections. Research cares little for personality traits, like extroversion or even ambition. All they want is a proficient worker who doesn't mind the tedium of lab work. You could be full blown Autistic and it wouldn't matter. Anyway, the important thing is to have personal connections with whoever is running the lab. If you're on good terms with him or her, you'll probably get the job. It was important to speak honestly about you abilities, but not be hesitant to state that you are good at something.
Interview Questions:
Can you keep doing what you did in the previous lab you worked in?
How long will it take before you're ready to start?
When can you have this project completed by?

title: Marketing Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 10 months. I interviewed at University of Houston System (Houston, TX) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions:
Online application. 8 months wait. Then a phone call. Then 1 month wait. Then in-person. Then 1 months wait. Then offer letter, then 2 months wait to join.
Yes, the whole process took one year. I am not sure I made the right choice after joining.

Post hiring, there was a disagreement between the hiring manager and HR on salary of the position. HR wanted to pay higher than hiring manager which was agreed upon by phone call. This caused further delay of 2 months. Finally got the offer with the promised higher salary from HR. 

That was the first red flag.
Interview Questions:
What are your plans to work?
yes....it is not long term or short term, but just work. It was a question that I just couldn't answer...

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview

Questions can vary from background information to brain teasers to see how an applicant has used their skills in the past or possess the ability to think and react under pressure. Some positions require multiple interviews in succession while others involve just one or more testing procedures.

title: Associate Director Interview

The closing date was that day so I took a chance and emailed the hiring manager about whether I should still apply since it was a sure bet that they already had a lot of applicants. The manager sent back an immediate reply that the department would welcome my application. Soon after I sent my resume and cover letter, I was invited for an interview cycle.
Interview Questions: Most of the questions were standard behavior-based interview questions ("Tell us about a time when...") with a couple more hard-hitting questions about why I wanted to work at UH. One interviewer didn't seem satisfied with my responses and no matter what I said, she kept asking the same question but phrased slightly differently each time. I was starting to get frustrated but I stayed calm and later I found out that she recommended that I be hired.
